Nashville — Shownotes S01E06

By: Mailed on: November 19, 2012

Dear , ,

Dear Cast and Crew of Nashville, S1E06 – “You’re Gonna Change (Or I’m Gonna Leave)”

Episode synopsis:
Rayna seeks the help of a music producer to change her sound, Juliette goes on a date with an NFL player in an attempt to repair her image, and Lamar’s plan to delay Coleman’s arrival at a photo op works too well.

Original air date:
November 14, 2012

Shownotes:

  • If the first thing someone says about your song is “it’s… different”, take the hint.
  • @JulietteBarnes2 has 20,000 new follower “requests” after her monkey stunt? Well she only has 1,223 followers right now. She might want to loosen up those Twitter settings.
  • Do PR people actually set stars up on dates? I feel so naïve.
  • This funky alt country song Avery is playing works well. I almost don’t mind that he’s such a spotlight whore, even as a vocalist.
  • Treme alert! Don’t be fooled, Rayna, that new “it” music producer is actually a street musician junkie from New Orleans!
  • Even if you look like Juliette, would any NFL player find it sexy for his “fake date” to chew him out on six incomplete passes? I feel so naïve.
  • I’ll have to pause and zoom in on that “Clean Campaign Pledge” Teddy is signing. I only caught the word “stereotype” and might ask the show’s writers to sign something similar.
  • Flying on a private jet to go nightclubbing in Miami? Believable. The fact this NFL QB can play Juliette’s songs on guitar because he has a little sister? I used that excuse to learn a Bieber song once. No one believed me, either.
  • You have to love network TV naughtiness: “Screw what? Rehearsing?” “No.” Cut to shot of the cougar lady manager (Ed. Technically it’s a shaguar)
  • Cinematographer Ross Berryman must have been dying to let loose on those Dutch angles when Rayna gets drunk.
  • I shouldn’t be surprised, but Rayna’s new song just doesn’t live up to all the hype she gave it.
  • Wait. WAIT. Deacon wasn’t willing to “pay the price” of having a successful solo career because he would have had to sleep with the cougar manager? She’s still a fox, 20 years later! (Ed. Too many sexy zoological references)
  • Now “I’ll-do-anything-to-get-ahead” Avery won’t sleep with her? This show is losing all credibility.
  • And now Scarlett is flying off the rails just because Avery had an option to sleep with her? She’s severely less cute when on the crazy juice.
  • I’ve heard of Stay-cations for budget conscious travelers, but “hanging-in” (vs. hanging-out”) is a new one. We used to just call that sex. I feel so naïve.
  • Knock knock. Who’s there? Avery. Avery who? The real Avery, who is willing to “pay the price” to be a star. A rather attractive price, I’ll remind you.

Closing comments: Despite some hard-to-swallow plot points (or maybe these Southerners are as moral as they preach), the show is weaving a nice web of controversies.  Episode six added a few new characters to the mix, and is finding nice ways to pair up the dramas (pictures catching people in the act, substance abuse issues, controversial song-writing partners, etc.).  And once again, the show gave us at least one or two noteworthy new songs.

Signed,

Christopher Redmond

Status: (/5)
